The ui of the app is really great. It is still missing some feature but so far it has been one of the best password managers on the market
Finally here! I love 1password!

Very good beta with big improvement from the original read-only release. Some things still need to be added such as linking browser addin so we can get away from 1PasswordX. Don't get me wrong, 1PasswordX has been a great bridge to Linux and it is useful, but getting the same experience I had when I used 1Password on a Mac is where I would like to get to with Linux too.
Works great on Ubuntu 20.10
This is good, but please allow us to save TOTP 2FA tokens. It's frustrating entering one every time you start the app.

description: The UI is great, and more importantly, it's fast.

This is a browser based "native" app which consumes a ton of memory. There is no difference between browser plugin and that one. 

At least the plugin is less resource hungy.
I have used it for years! Still very happy with it.

1Password as a secure vault, amazing. Other platform stand-alone versions, fantastic. Linux version being subscription only, no thanks. (A password vault should NEVER be located on someone else's equipment, require an internet connection to use, and not be subjected to unwanted surprises if a company goes under, is sold to an untrusted owner, or you have reasons to stop renting the client.)
The apps looks good so far and I appreciate the linux support.
This is nothing more than a browser plugin pretending to be native.
Thanks for the Linux support!

I have been using 1Password for a few years now and it is an essential tool on every one of my computing devices. I was very excited when the standalone app got official Linux support, as the browser plugin alone is less useful than when combined with the external app.

But multiple features that make the app great and useful are not available when running as a snap package, including the ability to "trust" the device (to stop asking for 2FA codes every single login), and critically, the ability to communicate with the browser! I recommend downloading the .deb file from the 1password website, instead.

Both ways I try to log in (either directly in the app or with a web redirect), the app hangs on "Adding your account.\n This may take a minute..."

I think it's waiting for me to do 2FA (through YubiKey) but there is no prompt to do so. So, it's useless to me right now.
since the update today it only shows a blank white screen. nothing helps. re-install reboot always the same issue.

Hello,

I've used 1Password for years. I'm currently getting a solid white screen when I try to run the local app on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS.

I see 1Password as a mixed blessing. It was better when it had fewer features; now it seems gratuitously complex.
1password only shows a blank screen after a recent update and is no longer usable

For those who are experiencing the white screen of doom. You can fix the issue by installing directly from 1password deb installation available from there website.

1password.com/downloads/linux
I can not login at all
Unable to login to this application therefore rendering this useless.

Having worked with 1Password on Windows for a while, and on Mac OS X/macOS for years, I was eager to test it on Ubuntu. 1Pwd in the current stable version 8.2.1 on Ubuntu 21.04 is working nicely. 

It connects to my vaults in the EU and the US, shows all the app and website icons, but fails to download the icons I've applied to entries. 

There is no way to select only certain vaults to show, so my 'archive' vault entries show up in all search results, which is annoying and confusing. 

Categories are completely missing, so showing all, say, Email accounts, Servers, Documents etc. is not easily possible. 

The icon in the 'system tray' (that is what 1Password calls what Ubuntu names the 'Top Bar', whatever) is barely functional and in no way comparable to the rich features on other operating systems.

Installing a browser extension is not synchronizing with the locally installed app, instead, it openes its own connection to the 1Password vaults in the cloud, keeps its own local copy and generally works independently. This is great if passwords are only needed in a browser, and very redundant, when the local app is installed. Unlock is not synchronized either, so I need to unlock each app/addon on its own. Annoying.

But other than that, it works, it manages the 1000+ entries without problems, it shows my self-defined field titles (and content, of course), the internal links between documents and logins (or whatever) are retained etc.

1Password is planning to move from native apps to Electron/Rust. I hope that will allow the Linux client to be feature complete compared to other platforms. Until then, it's okay.
summary: Works nicely on Ubuntu 21.04. Not feature-complete, though

description: seems to work just fine
The developper is taking time to make it work just as well on linux as other mainstream operating systems and you can see it. One of the best password managers on Linux right now.
i think it's good at the time but need to give some more updates in future

Very similar look & operation to Mac & Windows desktop apps. 1Password-Linux behaves like a web login to your 1Password account. Both work as expected, I prefer the desktop app behaviour. More a matter of preference than functionality...

I recommend installing the browser-embedded version of 1Password as well. Can be done during client setup on 1Password's website, or as an add-on in Firefox.
Would really like to see the default account/vault feature that we get on other platforms though.
Works fine until you need to edit an entry. Fails with an unknown error

I own 1password licenses for iOS, Mac and Windows bought when they used to sell software and allowed you to sync your vault via Dropbox. Linux version only works if you buy the freaking monthly subscription.

description: It's sandboxed. So not all functions can be used. To bad.
Every other version doesn't work.

Started with my Mac. Did not realize there is now a Linux version. Sure, it is sandboxed but who cares. Works great! The initial sign-in did not work through the "online" link but I just manually put in my information and, boom, 1Password on Linux.

Love this!

My life is so much easier since using 1password. I tried out bascially all alternatives, (keypassxc, lastpass, bitwarden) but 1password is by far the most comfortable one to use.

I can use it as authenticator app for hassle-free 2FA. 

The browser add-on is great and very reliable at detecting and autofilling forms. Even for 2FA codes.

Then they have the app. This is just great for the things that are not browser like ... software applications where alt-tab, search and one-click copy works so much smoother than a browser add-on. Also call me old fashioned but I prefer something where I can right-click for managing (like deleting or archiving) old passwords.

And finally they have a great CLI for scripting and work-related stuff. 

I really like that for each usecase there is dedicated solution that just works fluently. The only minus point I have is each add-on, app and CLI need to have the password entered seperately. Especially due to snap sandboxing they can't unlock each other. That would be the cherry on top.
Functions as expected. Note that due to Snap limitations, the Snap version of 1Password cannot communicate with your browser (you will need to login on both pieces of software separately at times)
This app is very stable at the moment
When I try to login and open the link in the app, nothing happens.
1Password for Linux is da bomb!
The best password manager.
Ever since they rewrote it in Rust it has been a fantastic experience
Fast, convenient and safety. It's the coolest native client!
The App works fine, Browser extension authentication also works.
Especially with the release of version 8.
summary: Very well put together password manager

description: The only password manager needed across all devices

I love 1Password. In today's day and age with hundreds or thousands of passwords I can't imaging not having a password manager. I considered multiple options and used various password managers over the years and 1Pass if my favorite by far. My venture with 1Pass started almost 5 years ago and I have reccomended to to friends and several small businesses I help. I see a long future with it.

I honestly do not know how anyone calls themselves a computer user without 1P. I have it on every device I own, and it's saved my bacon more times than I can count.

The built-in SSH agent is one of my favorite features--you can store your private keys in the vault, and the SSH agent can access them with your approval whenever prompted. Very handy.
The app has some Bugs, but it is to expect from a beta software. Thanks for releasing the Linux version.
summary: Happy to finally see a linux app for 1Password

description: Using it for > 10 years now. Easy to use on PCs, laptops and mobile devices.
summary: Essential on the Mac, now finally on Linux
